description.narrative:
SORUDA will work with Oxfam with an overall objective to mitigate the impact of locust invasion and disaster preparedness of Katakwi District.
Specific Objectives 1. To provide basic package of fast-maturing crops to 500 most vulnerable households in Katakwi District by August 2020 2. To build capacity of District Disaster Management Committee in Katakwi District to plan respond disaster byAugust 2020 SORUDA will implement this project in Katakwi District in liaison with the District Production Office and Army ResponseTeam for Locusts so that there is coordinated efforts. Specifically, the Production Office will support in agreeing on distributionof beneficiaries based on the criteria and in capacity building. Likewise, it will host the Disaster Management Committee for orientation on their planning role and influencing resource allocation. Our partner SORUDA has her main office in Soroti District and will be the direct implementor with technical backstopping from the EFSVL Coordinator. SORUDA#s technical human resource capacity and infrastructure to provide this immediate assistance. Planned activities planned include: # Project inception <(>&<)> Initial sensitization meetings with leaders and communities. # Mapping out of most affected locations, sub-counties and prioritization of interventions. # Mobilization and selection, sensitization of beneficiaries and service providers # Provide basic package of fast maturing crops to the affected households # Develop farmer-to-farmer good agronomic practices for the fast maturing crops # Capacity building ofdistrict <(>&<)> sub county disaster management committees through training (disaster risk identification, stages, planning and response) # Monitor the Implementation and document best practices

participating-org.narrative:
SORUDA formerly Soroti Rural Development Agency, was initiated by a group of volunteers to address aftermath of challenges arising from civil and political conflict. Its focus was to target rural communities who were returning to their homes by addressing their livelihood and food security needs. Legally, it got registered in 2000 with Ministry of internal affairs NGO board registration No. S.5914/2928. Thereafter, because of the decentralisation policy, the mother Soroti was sub divided to form eight Districts and legally SORUDA had to rebrand to take its acronym as a name and renewed its operation country wide. Increasing SORUDA was able to develop policies among which is the gender policy that guides SORUDA#s delivery of services to target 50% femaleparticipation. 2. ACHIEVEMENTS Program/project coverage has increased and interventions taken closure to communities specifically priorities given to female headed households, girls and Persons with Special Needs (PSN). Out of the targeting, SORUDA hasbeen able to reach 25,000 (11,000 male and 14,000 Females) participating households covering areas of Teso, Lango, Karamoja and some parts of west Nile (Adjumani). Developed simple group savings and loan schemes for purposes of improving access to smallfinancial services that do not have collaterals Introduced disaster preparedness grain storage facilities using improved technologies such as use of super grain bags, plastic and metallic silos Strengthened production and productivity Established a community network to address challenges of women and girl child abuses through community surveillance system and District production departments for disasters
3. INSTITUTIONAL PURPOSE To promotesustainable rural development through community driveneradication initiatives, good governance and emancipation initiatives
To carry out capacity building through training in group development, advisory services and research. # To contribute to reduction of poverty in the rural poor communities # To empower women and carry out advocacy and sensitization on Child rights # To promote environment conservation and management # To promote peace building and conflict resolution in East, North and West Nile regions
SORUDA#s activities and programme competences are organized around four main thematic areas namely; 1) Support Livelihood interventions; 2) Human rights and Good Governance 3) Water, Sanitation and Hygiene promotion 4) Emergency response and Disaster Risk Reduction 5) HIV/AIDS advocacy onprevention SORUDA has intervened in the rural communities of Teso, Karamoja, Lango, Acholi and West Nile regions in Uganda with interventions targeting farmers, youth in and out of school, children, pregnant mothers, Persons Living with HIV/AIDS and displaced persons 4. STRATEGIC POSITIONING SORUDA has intervened in communities displaces, refugees and has worked in Teso, Karamoja, Lango, Acholi and West Nile. SORUDA has worked in hard to reach areas targeting the rural underserved and poverty strickencommunities. SORUDA has worked with Local Government structures, religious and Cultural sectors and other CSOs. The named actors supported in community mobilisation, sensitization beneficiary identification, security provision and complementary support
SORUDA has adequate human and logistic resources Community presence and existence Ability to quickly respond to emergency situations in the community.
